conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the velocity-time graphs of cars A and B to determine if their displacements are the same.
Calculate the area under each graph, which represents the displacement, and compare the results.

The image shows two velocity-time graphs labeled A and B. Graph A is a curve starting from the origin, increasing to a maximum velocity, and then decreasing back to the origin. Graph B is a curve starting from the origin, decreasing to a minimum velocity, and then increasing back to the origin. Both graphs are enclosed within a rectangle from t=0 to t=t1.
The displacement of an object is calculated by integrating its velocity over time. The area under the velocity-time graphs represents the displacement.
For car A, the graph starts and ends at the origin, forming a closed loop. The area under this graph is zero because the starting and ending points are the same.
For car B, the graph also starts and ends at the origin, forming another closed loop. The area under this graph is also zero for the same reason.
Since both graphs have zero area under them, the displacements of cars A and B are the same.
The question asks if the displacements are the same, and based on the analysis, the answer is yes.
